content.body: I've considered using an infix `~` as an indicator for partial application, i.e. `obj.method~(a, ?)`, so `obj~[key]` might be reasonable. Thin-arrow is possible as well (i.e., `obj->[key]`), though that sequence of tokens get's in to "`obj.get` is easier to write" territory
content.formatted_body: I've considered using an infix ~ as an indicator for partial application, i.e. obj.method~(a, ?), so obj~[key] might be reasonable. Thin-arrow is possible as well (i.e., obj->[key]), though that sequence of tokens get's in to "obj.get is easier to write" territory

content.body: We at Agoric are also hoping to use `remote~.method()` for async method invocation on a promise/placeholder for a remote object, `remoteFunction~()` for async function application, and `promise~.propertyName` for async get.
content.formatted_body: We at Agoric are also hoping to use remote~.method() for async method invocation on a promise/placeholder for a remote object, remoteFunction~() for async function application, and promise~.propertyName for async get.

content.body: (On the mnemonic that `~` resembles a stream and each of these would be used to stream operations to remote objects.)
content.formatted_body: (On the mnemonic that ~ resembles a stream and each of these would be used to stream operations to remote objects.)

content.body: If `f~()` gets used for that, then I don't think there's any syntax that would ever work for partial application.
content.formatted_body: If f~() gets used for that, then I don't think there's any syntax that would ever work for partial application.

content.body: If you used`f~.()` it would be consistent with `f?.()` at least, though I imagine `f~.~()` would end up being a bridge too far.
content.formatted_body: If you usedf~.() it would be consistent with f?.() at least, though I imagine f~.~() would end up being a bridge too far.

content.body: I still hold out hope for partial application, which is why I haven't withdrawn it, but where I left it one of the things it needed was a prefix token for the argument list. For a number of reasons I've discussed on the issue tracker, the token can't come *before* the method/function name since it has the wrong precedence for binding, and for partial application to be practically useful it can't have an arduous syntax.
content.formatted_body: I still hold out hope for partial application, which is why I haven't withdrawn it, but where I left it one of the things it needed was a prefix token for the argument list. For a number of reasons I've discussed on the issue tracker, the token can't come before the method/function name since it has the wrong precedence for binding, and for partial application to be practically useful it can't have an arduous syntax.

content.body: One of the things that the original `f(?)` syntax for partial app lacked was the ability to indicate a partial 0-arity invocation, i.e. `obj.method()` isn't partial, and there's no way to defer its invocation, while `object.method~()` allows for 0-arity partial application.
content.formatted_body: One of the things that the original f(?) syntax for partial app lacked was the ability to indicate a partial 0-arity invocation, i.e. obj.method() isn't partial, and there's no way to defer its invocation, while object.method~() allows for 0-arity partial application.

content.body: The other upshot of using `~.` for async invocation, is that you're not limited to `~` as there are a number of other symbols that are currently illegal before `.` in that position.
content.formatted_body: The other upshot of using ~. for async invocation, is that you're not limited to ~ as there are a number of other symbols that are currently illegal before . in that position.

content.body: This is also why I'm not a fan of using up our syntax budget on `a[@x]` when we primarily want to support a narrow case for a small set of objects (`Slice`, `Index`, maybe `WeakMap` or a set of user-defined objects like `Pick`, etc.) that could easily be accomplished with `a[x]`.
content.formatted_body: This is also why I'm not a fan of using up our syntax budget on a[@x] when we primarily want to support a narrow case for a small set of objects (Slice, Index, maybe WeakMap or a set of user-defined objects like Pick, etc.) that could easily be accomplished with a[x].

content.body: Whatever we used for that would impact what's available for future proposals. i.e., any symbol in the place of `@` in `a[@x]` means that symbol can never be used in a prefix position of an AssignmentExpression. A symbol before `[` doesn't have that issue, but we have an even smaller number of symbols we can legally put before `[` and still have it be somewhat ergonomic to type.
content.formatted_body: Whatever we used for that would impact what's available for future proposals. i.e., any symbol in the place of @ in a[@x] means that symbol can never be used in a prefix position of an AssignmentExpression. A symbol before [ doesn't have that issue, but we have an even smaller number of symbols we can legally put before [ and still have it be somewhat ergonomic to type.

content.body: I'd love to be able to hook `a[x]` for _numeric_ indexes, since that also gives us a way to make things like Array and TypedArray into regular objects instead of exotic objects. It also opens the door for user-defined numeric-indexed collection classes that work like `Array`, which can only be implemented via a `Proxy` today.
content.formatted_body: I'd love to be able to hook a[x] for numeric indexes, since that also gives us a way to make things like Array and TypedArray into regular objects instead of exotic objects. It also opens the door for user-defined numeric-indexed collection classes that work like Array, which can only be implemented via a Proxy today.

content.body:
> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> We at Agoric are also hoping to use `remote~.method()` for async method invocation on a promise/placeholder for a remote object, `remoteFunction~()` for async function application, and `promise~.propertyName` for async get.

I'd like to update Extension proposal in recent future meetings, one use case in the original proposal is to support eventual send with Extension syntax, in the original draft, it is `promise::Eventual:method()` and `promise::Eventual:propertyName`. I think the old eventual send proposal do not have `remoteFunction()` feature, is it ok to use `remoteFunction::Eventual:call()` for that? (note, I plan to change `::` and `:` delimiters, but I assume it should not the big issue for this case)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org
We at Agoric are also hoping to use remote~.method() for async method invocation on a promise/placeholder for a remote object, remoteFunction~() for async function application, and promise~.propertyName for async get.
I'd like to update Extension proposal in recent future meetings, one use case in the original proposal is to support eventual send with Extension syntax, in the original draft, it is promise::Eventual:method() and promise::Eventual:propertyName. I think the old eventual send proposal do not have remoteFunction() feature, is it ok to use remoteFunction::Eventual:call() for that? (note, I plan to change :: and : delimiters, but I assume it should not the big issue for this case)

content.body: i feel like some things should remain as DSLs
or, in a versatile enough language, just libraries

I agree with Chris. It's much harder to validate tests without also writing an implementation. I'm wondering if it makes more sense to split the "implementation" part into two parts: the development/validation of the feature internally or flagged, and _shipping_ the implementation unflagged.
content.formatted_body: I agree with Chris. It's much harder to validate tests without also writing an implementation. I'm wondering if it makes more sense to split the "implementation" part into two parts: the development/validation of the feature internally or flagged, and shipping the implementation unflagged.
